marketNews.title: BI Rate Cut After Trump Lowers Indonesia Tariffs
marketNews.content:
Bank Indonesia decided to cut the BI Rate by 25 basis points to 5.25% on Wednesday, 16 July, with the deposit facility and lending facility also each reduced by 25 basis points to 4.5% and 6% respectively. Prior to the announcement, Bloomberg consensus expectations were split, with 55% expecting the BI Rate to remain unchanged and 45% expecting a 25-basis-point cut.

Governor Perry Warjiyo explained that the decision considered: 1) inflation and core inflation projections for the next two years that remain low below the midpoint of the target range ±2.5%; 2) stability of the rupiah exchange rate; and 3) the effort to support economic growth. Bank Indonesia maintains its economic growth target at 4.6-5.4% year-on-year for 2025, which had been downgraded twice earlier this year.

Bank Indonesia reported that bank credit growth slowed to +7.77% YoY in the first half of 2025 (versus +8.43% YoY in the first five months), marking the weakest growth since June 2023 and below the downgraded 2025 target range of +8-11% YoY. The result was pressured by banks’ preference to keep liquid funds in securities and a cautious stance in loan disbursement. Nevertheless, the Governor said the bank still keeps the 2025 credit-growth target at +8-11% YoY, driven by expectations of improvement in the second half of 2025 as a trade agreement with the United States materialises.

Perry said that trade uncertainty is gradually easing as the United States reduced tariffs on Indonesian products from the previous 32% to 19%. He noted that a lower policy rate could boost credit growth, while the tariff agreement is expected to help businesses make forward-looking decisions.

Regarding the newly announced tariff reduction, the Secretary of the Coordinating Ministry for Economic Affairs, Susiwijono Moegiarso, told Bloomberg that the government is preparing a joint statement with the United States that will detail additional information on the agreement. The key points of the trade deal, according to U.S. President Donald Trump, are:

1. Indonesia will not impose import tariffs or non-tariff barriers on U.S. goods.
2. Indonesia will agree to import energy from the United States worth USD 15 billion, U.S. agricultural products worth USD 4.5 billion, and 50 Boeing aircraft. The time frame for these imports has not been disclosed.
3. Trump added that “if there is transshipment from a country with a higher tariff, that tariff will be added to the tariff paid by Indonesia.”

Key Takeaway: In response to these two developments, the rupiah weakened 0.11% to 16,278 per dollar, while the 10-year government bond yield remained flat at 6.573% on Wednesday. The Jakarta Composite Index rose 0.7% to 7,192, driven mainly by large-cap stocks $DCII (+19.99%) and $DSSA (+3.86%). Big banks moved mixed with small gains or losses under 2%.

marketNews.title: Other Hot Topics You Need to Know
marketNews.content:
1. Bank Indonesia recorded that bank credit growth slowed to +7.77% YoY in 1H25 (vs +8.43% YoY in 5M25), the weakest since June 2023 and below the downgraded 2025 target range of +8-11% YoY. Investment credit grew +12.53% YoY (vs +13.74% YoY in 5M25), consumption credit +8.49% YoY (vs +8.82% YoY), and working-capital credit +4.45% YoY (vs +4.94% YoY). Sharia financing grew +8.37% YoY (vs +9.19% YoY) and MSME credit grew +2.18% YoY (vs +2.17% YoY).
2. Deputy Finance Minister Anggito Abimanyu said the Ministry of Finance is studying the expansion of excise tax objects by adding sodium-rich processed food products (P2OB) such as packaged snacks as a new excise item in the 2026 fiscal year. In addition, the ministry is examining excise on other commodities, including plastics, fuel oil (BBM), sweetened packaged beverages (MBDK), and the shift of luxury goods sales tax (PPnBM) on motor vehicles to an excise regime.
3. U.S. Bureau of Statistics reported that the U.S. consumer price index (CPI) rose 2.7% YoY in June 2025 (vs 2.4% YoY in May 2025), above the consensus expectation of 2.6% YoY and the highest since February 2025. On a monthly basis, U.S. inflation was 0.3% MoM (vs 0.1% MoM in May), matching consensus and marking the biggest rise in five months. Core inflation increased to 0.2% MoM and 2.9% YoY (vs 0.1% MoM and 2.8% YoY in May), monthly below consensus of 0.3% MoM and annual in line with consensus.
4. U.S. President Donald Trump said on Tuesday, 15 July, that he is likely to impose import tariffs on pharmaceutical products as early as the end of July 2025. He indicated the tariffs would start low and later rise to 200% after giving companies one year to build factories in the United States. Trump also said he will soon impose tariffs on imported semiconductors, without further details.
5. Pefindo economist Suhindarto stated that total Indonesian corporate bond issuance reached IDR 90.9 trillion in 1H25 (+48% YoY), with bonds and sukuk accounting for IDR 90.3 trillion (+50% YoY) and the remainder consisting of medium-term notes and securitizations. Regarding purpose, refinancing accounted for IDR 31.5 trillion (+107% YoY) and working-capital issuance for IDR 56.3 trillion (+46% YoY). He noted that corporate bond maturities will reach IDR 161 trillion in 2025, with the majority maturing in the second half of 2025.
6. Coordinating Minister for Food Affairs Zulkifli Hasan said the launch of the Red-White Village Cooperative (Kopdes Merah Putih) was postponed from 19 July 2025 to 21 July 2025 so that relevant officials could attend and hear President Prabowo Subianto’s directives directly. Previously, the launch had been moved from 12 July 2025 because President Prabowo had other overseas commitments. Deputy Minister of Cooperatives Ferry Juliantono said the initial financing for Kopdes Merah Putih will be provided through a special KUR with a ceiling of up to IDR 3 billion per cooperative.

tickerNews.title: TPIA Clarifies Rumor of JV Acquisition of Exxon Fuel Stations
tickerNews.content: Chandra Asri Pacific clarified to the IDX that there is no definitive agreement regarding the rumored joint venture in which the company was said to plan to acquire Exxon Mobil’s fuel station business in Singapore. TPIA stated that the company remains open to opportunities that support sustainable business growth. The clarification followed a Bloomberg report last week that Aster Chemicals and Energy – a joint venture between TPIA and Glencore – was in talks to purchase the Exxon Mobil fuel station business in Singapore, with Bloomberg citing ongoing negotiations on price and transaction structure.

tickerNews.title: DATA Secures IDR 250 Billion Working-Capital Loan from BBCA
tickerNews.content: Remala Abadi, together with its subsidiary PT PC 24 Cyber Indonesia, signed a working-capital loan facility of up to IDR 250 billion with Bank Central Asia (BBCA). The facility has a tenor of one year.

tickerNews.title: MTEL Denies Merger Rumor with TBIG
tickerNews.content: Dayamitra Telekomunikasi clarified to the IDX that the company has no information regarding the rumored merger plan with Tower Bersama Infrastructure (TBIG). MTEL added that it continuously evaluates strategic options to create the best value for shareholders. In a separate filing, TBIG stated that it also has no information about any merger rumor with MTEL and that no agreement has been signed. The clarifications came after Bloomberg reported last week that MTEL was reconsidering a merger with TBIG, following a previous attempt that failed in 2015.

tickerNews.title: WIKA Reports New Contract Value of IDR 4.3 Trillion in 1H25
tickerNews.content: Wijaya Karya’s corporate secretary, Ngatemin, told Kontan that the company recorded new contract values of IDR 4.3 trillion in the first half of 2025, a 58% year-on-year decline. New contracts were dominated by the industrial sector (58.86%), followed by infrastructure and building (34%) and EPC and property (7.14%).

tickerNews.title: CGAS Receives Government Allocation for Gas from Pertamina EP Zone 7
tickerNews.content: Citra Nusantara Gemilang announced that it has received a government letter assigning allocation and utilization of natural gas from the Pertamina EP Zone 7 mining field. The daily delivery amount is set at 1.5 MMSCFD and the total contract volume is 4,110 MMSCF. CGAS explained that this allocation is the initial step for the LNG Station Galian Karawang project, aligned with the intended use of IPO proceeds.
